text: I do this way too much.  It's part of my more general problem with excessive planning getting in the way of ever actually doing anything.  Spend so much time thinking about how to make the initial implementation of something absolutely perfect that I just never do it

text:
Def a fine line between scoping out a project and wasting time.

I find that having people review your proposed idea and poking holes to find edge cases which you may have missed being handy

Then just go ahead and start building it and you’ll probably find a couple others which you may have missed

text: part of it for me is that when I do just forge ahead and start doing things, I inevitably make stupid mistakes and think to myself "man, I'm such an idiot, if only I had carefully thought this through", but this completely misses the fact that in many such cases, "carefully thinking it through" would have taken much more time than bumbling along a bit and immediately fixing it

text:
Usually when starting a bit of a bigger project I’ll make a document similar to;

> <https://gist.github.com/mattBrzezinski/a87f61e6fe85ff0bcc7cdee9e5f943a3>
I find that it lets me capture everything that’s important, what’s the issue I’m solving, what are any constraints and things to consider, etc.

That way I feel some confidence that this isn’t something I’ve started to slap together, and gives justification to decisions made
